awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Uncovering and Utilizing the Dynamic Interplay between Work Recovery and Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
All employees will, at some point, encounter workplace adversities such as work overload, role ambiguity, interpersonal conflict, abusive supervision, or work-family conflict. Thus, there is a critical need to identify pathways through which employees can achieve work effectiveness and wellbeing, despite facing difficulties. Work resilience -- positive adaptation despite adversity at work -- is an advantageous tool that offers a path to success despite adverse experiences. We propose one unexplored way to increase resilience is through recovery, in which non-work time is used to recuperate from fatigue and negative mood built up during the work day. This project's goal is to understand how psychological (e.g., detachment from work, relaxation) and physical (e.g., sleep, exercise) recovery experiences relate to work resilience. Determining behaviors that improve resilience which are under individuals' control during their non-work time has the potential to benefit individuals, teams, and organizations across every occupation. 

The goal of this project is to uncover and model the dynamic interrelationship of psychological and physical work recovery experiences with work resilience. This project: 1) assesses potential psychological (fatigue) and physiological (heart rate variability) mechanisms that link work recovery and resilience; 2) examines the differential effects of alternative work recovery experiences (i.e., psychological and physical) on work resilience; and 3) delineates the temporal dynamics between work recovery and resilience, uncovering potential cumulative and reciprocal effects. We will conduct two experience sampling research studies using (a) a sample of traditionally employed participants who work during standard weekly business hours and (b) a sample of shift workers - employees who work alternative shifts that at least partially fall outside the daytime shift range (e.g., night shift and rotating shift employees) - to test the current model. Each study is a four-week daily survey study in a sample of 100 working adults that incorporates both objective behavioral and physiological indicators. By explicating the relative importance of different recovery experiences contributing to work resilience and the dynamic relationship between work recovery and resilience, this project could provide a theoretical foundation to enhance organizational effectiveness and employee wellbeing despite unavoidable adversities. Findings will be shared with research outlets, business practitioners, policy makers, and community members.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Employees commonly encounter difficulties and challenges at work that require them to demonstrate resilience. Employee resilience reflects the ability to bounce back from adversities that are encountered at work. Being resilient in response to adversity is critical to employee success and work performance both from day-to-day and over longer time intervals. Effective work recovery, a widely recognized contributor to employee wellness and performance that represents the replenishment of energy drained by working during time away from work, may be critical to allowing employees to put forth the effort necessary to be resilient when facing adversity. However, despite the potential promise that effective work recovery may hold for supporting employee resilience over time, whether and how work recovery influences and is influenced by employee resilience had yet to be established at the onset of this project.

The goal of this project was to demonstrate that employee resilience and work recovery relate to and are influenced by each other over time across distinct adult working populations. Particular emphasis was placed on evaluating similarities and differences in how physical inputs to work recovery (such as exercise, sleep, and diet) and psychological inputs to work recovery (such as disconnecting from work during post-work time and having control over how one’s post-work time is spent) contribute to employee resilience. Attention was also given to the potential for differences in employee resilience – work recovery relationships when comparing employees working fixed, predictable schedules (Monday – Friday, roughly 9 a.m. – 5 p.m. each week) to shift working employees (employees working on different days, at varying times of day, and/or on overnight shifts). Finally, we also considered whether daily work experiences that are more frustrating (i.e., prevent employees from accomplishing their work goals) or more challenging (i.e., allow employees to apply their knowledge, skills, and abilities towards the accomplishment of their work goals) may have differing implications for contributors to employee resilience and work recovery both from day-to-day and over longer time intervals.

The primary data collection supported through the project leveraged a 28-day study of employees’ daily experiences at work and at home to accomplish the overarching project goal of understanding how employee resilience and work recovery relate over time. Participants completed multiple within-day surveys tracking their daily experiences, while also providing data through wearable devices tracking physical activity, sleep, and heart rate variability. Data collection efforts resulted in usable data from 133 participants encompassing both employees working fixed, predictable schedules and shift workers. We complemented insights from this primary data collection supported through the project with preliminary pilot data collected from 98 working sole mothers who completed twice daily surveys across seven consecutive days.

Across three peer-reviewed publications, five national conference presentations, a Ph.D. student’s dissertation, and numerous presentations to academic and applied audiences, project findings yielded compelling insights that advanced understanding of the dynamic interplay of employee resilience and work recovery over time in different working adult populations. Most notably, findings from this project have expanded understanding of employee resilience, work recovery, and their interplay by showing that (1) having greater control over how non-work time is spent influences some physical contributors to daily work recovery, such as leisure-time exercise engagement, (2) encountering different types of daily work demands, such as frustrating vs. challenging workday experiences, appears crucial to understanding how recovery and contributors to resilience, such as sleep and negative thoughts about work, relate over time, and that (3) work scheduling factors may play a particularly critical role in explaining how work recovery relates to criteria, such as employee resilience, over time. On the latter point specifically, this project led to the development of a conceptual framework to understand how the timing and scheduling of work periods and recovery opportunities can influence work recovery and the implications of this recovery for organizationally valued outcomes such as resilience. This framework is expected to bolster future research and applications focused on understanding how the process of recovering from work is relevant to maintaining employee resilience over both acute and chronic time intervals.

Beyond these impacts to organizational theory, research, and practical applications, the project provided critical training, professional development, and research support to four Ph.D. students who can leverage the advanced conceptual, methodological, and quantitative training that they received while working on the project to launch their own impactful careers focused on making a difference in the lives of employees and organizational stakeholders. Ultimately, the scholarly, practical, and professional impacts of this project are intended to provide the foundations to catalyze efforts to harness the positive potential of employee resilience and work recovery to support employees in meeting their work goals while maintaining their health and wellness over shorter- and longer-term time intervals.
